Gerlee operates a transportation service in his town. He uses his motorcycle as a taxi to transport people around the local area. Gerlee started his business in 2005 with capital of 20,000 tugrugs. Over the last four years, he has managed to grow his business into a stable operation. Today, his working capital exceeds 300,000 tugrugs. He has many plans for the future and says, "I hope to save enough money to help my wife open a cafe." He is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan to purchase machinery parts for his motorcycle. 

About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.use: To purchase machinery parts for his motorcycle.

texts.en:

She has been involved in this type of retail sales for over 2 years. She is requesting a loan for business expansion and purchase of new medications.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of new medications

Mary, who makes a living as a seamstress, would like to buy a new sewing machine because her old one no longer works very well. Homa, who also works as a seamstress, needs to buy additional materials for her business.

loans.name: Nansalmaa

texts.en:
Nansalmaa B. lives with her husband and two sons in Tuv province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest son is eight years old and attends a local secondary school and her youngest, age four, is in kindergarten. Her husband is a senior fireman in the Mongolian army and will soon be going to Chad on a peacekeeping mission. Nansalmaa operates a clothes-making business in a small rented apartment in her town. She graduated as a dressmaker in 2001 and worked for seven years at sewing factory before opening her business in 2008. Nansalmaa has gained much experience in her trade over the years and is an open-minded and intelligent businesswoman. Today, she has a steady business operation and many loyal customers. She says, "I want to expand my business and be a good client who will pay my loan on time." Tsogttugs is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrik (MNT) loan to purchase a more advanced sewing machine for her business.

She says thank you to all who make this loan possible!

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi is a young man who is married with one child. Fadi owns a vehicle repair workshop in the Jenin Industrial area. Jenin is located in the northern West Bank and very close to the green line-borders with Israel. Since car repair costs much less in the West Bank than in Israel, Fadi has many customers, either Arabs inside Israel or locals from Jenin.

Fadi gained his car repair experience from his father who used to own this workshop. Four years ago, Fadi decided to buy this workshop from his father so as to have his own business, since he has other brothers.

In the workshop Fadi sells car tires and also fixes them, and repairs cars' motors; Fadi has two workers in this workshop in addition to himself, but in the mornings he is an employee at the maintenance department of Jenin muncipality. After finishing his work, he spends his time at the workshop. His father stays in the workshop in the morning just to see that everything is ok since he is elderly and can't do any actual work.

Fadi needs the loan to buy an auto crane, a car jack, tires and other equipment. Fadi appears in the picture at his business.

loans.use: Buy equipment for his workshop

loans.name: Nyamjav

texts.en:
D. Nyamjav is 58 years old and lives with his wife in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. He and his wife live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife conducts a clothes-trading business out of a rented stall at a local market in the town. Nyamjav operates a gold and silver crafts-making business. His profession consists mostly of crafting and welding his products as well as making repairs to metal items. 

Nyamjav started his business in 2003 and has been quite successful. His business continues to grow each year and today his working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugriks (MNT). Nyamjav has many plans for the future and says, "I am working hard and hope to have my own workplace in the future." He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrik  loan to refurbish his tools used in his gold and silver crafts business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To refurbish his tools used in his gold and silver crafts business.

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
T. Oyunchimeg is 51 years old and lives with her 13-year old son, Otgontugs, in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her son live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her son currently attends a  local secondary school. 

Oyunchimeg operates a meat and raw materials trading business in her town. She started her business in 2002 with capital of 50,000 tugriks (MNT). She has grown her business over the years and enjoys a stable operation today. She attributes her success to her good accounting skills, and today her working capital exceeds 800,000 tugriks. 

Oyunchimeg has much hope for the future and says, "I want to further expand my business in order to improve my life." She is requesting a 700,000 tugrik loan to purchase meat and raw materials to sell in her business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. loans.name: Sabreen

texts.en:
Sabreen, a 29 year-old married woman with one child, lives in Gaza, Palestine, where she owns a shop selling home appliances and kitchenware.

Today she is requesting a loan of $2,000 to buy more inventory to increase her client base. She says, "thank you!"

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of entrepreneur. In Palestine, it is culturally unacceptable to some people to post a picture of a woman to the Internet. However, the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Henry Kitsao

texts.en:
Henry Kitsao M. is 38 years old and has five children between the ages of 15 and 6 years old. He is married to Loice Nyevu. They live in Chakama-Malindi, where Henry has been a farmer for 13 years. 

Henry was introduced to KADET through a local coordinator and is on his second loan cycle. He had a previous loan of 12,500 Kenyan shillings (KES), which he paid back in full and on time.

Henry plans to use this loan to purchase petrol, seeds, fertilizer, and pesticides for his farming business. He plans to use his extra earnings from the loan to invest in a posho mill (a mill that grinds maize into corn flour) and he dreams of becoming an employer and creating jobs for others. He also hopes to be able to educate his children and improve the standard of living for his family. Henry describes himself as a hardworking Kenyan.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy petrol, seeds, fertilizer, pesticides.

loans.name: Alfred Mwakoi

texts.en:
Alfred Mwakoi M. is a single 23-year old man who was introduced to KADET by the coordinator in his group. He has been in the farming business for one year and also runs an agrivert (composting) shop in Chakama-Malindi.

His clients are mainly farmers in the same area of Chakama-Malindi. With this loan, he plans to buy farming supplies for his shop and boost his farming activities. He gets a monthly profit of 4,500 Kenyan shillings (KES) from his shop, and with the proceeds from this loan he hopes to establish a savings plan and be able to pay his loan back in full and on time.

Alfred describes himself as hardworking and very determined to improve his life. His ambition is to support fellow citizens through education and employment.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To hire labor and to buy seeds, petrol, and fertilizer.

Mariefe has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mariefe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mariefe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. 

Mariefe is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mariefe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Srey Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Mom O. lives in Pravong village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she earns a living by growing rice. She also runs a small business on the side making shoes. Because this business is doing well, she would like to expand it, and has applied for a loan to buy more of the materials she uses to make shoes. Her husband, Mr. Kun Kong, helps her run her business. The couple have three children, two of whom are in school, while the third is too young to work or study.

loans.use: to expand a small shoe-making business

loans.name: Ginorah Mkaluma

texts.en:
Ginorah Mkaluma M. is 27 years and married to Pius Mwaizinga with whom she has a 6-month old girl named Victoria. They live in Chakama-Malindi.

Ginorah was introduced to KADET by the coordinator in her group. She has been practicing farming for the last year and also runs an agrivert (green agriculture and composting) shop. Her customers are mainly farmers in Chakama-Malindi.

With this loan she hopes to boost her farm output and establish other agrivert shops in Malindi. Specifically, she will use the loan to buy seedlings, pesticides, and fertilizer. 

Ginorah describes herself as quiet and hardworking and dreams of building a home in Chakama.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy seedlings, pesticides, and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mariaflor

texts.en:
Mariaflor T. is from the village of San Andres, Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Mariaflor is married and has four grown children. 

To make a living, Mariaflor owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Mariaflor has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mariaflor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mariaflor has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Mariaflor is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mariaflor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Munkhtuya

texts.en:
Munkhtuya R. is 59 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Khovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son and daughter are university students and her youngest daughter attends a local secondary school.

Munkhtuya used to work as a nurse but now operates a small grocery shop in her town with the help of her husband. Her salary as a nurse was very low and she started her grocery shop in 2006 so that she could earn more money to support her family. Munkhtuya has found success with her new business and due to her good management has doubled her profits in just two years. She recently purchased a van using her savings from the business. 

Munkhtuya is focused on continuing her success in the future and says, "It is hard to live if in Mongolia if you don't conduct your own business. Our shop is the only source of income for my family, therefore, my dream is to continue to grow my business in the future." Munkhtuya is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrik (MNT) loan to purchase grocery items for her shop.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her shop.

loans.name: Adham

texts.en:
Adham owns a small barber shop in the center of Gaza city, Palestine. He is 31 years old and unmarried. Adham spends a lot of time serving his regular clients. Being very polite by nature and being professional at his job, he has gathered a lot of clients. 

Today, Adham is requesting a loan of $2,000 U.S. dollars from Ryada in order to change the décor of his salon.

loans.use: To change the décor of his salon.

loans.name: George Charo

texts.en:
George Charo N. is a 35-year old man married to Jumwa, who is a housewife. Together they have four children between the ages of 11 and 2 years. They live in Chakama, which is a few kilometers from Malindi.

George has been farming for ten years. He gets a monthly profit of 2,500 Kenyan shillings (KES) from his farm and he also works as a watchman providing security in Chakama. He is taking out his second loan from KADET. With this loan, he plans to buy three gallons of petrol and a water pump to boost his crop output. With the extra earnings from this loan he hopes to invest in a retail shop and in his childrens' education.

George describes himself as a focused and hardworking person and dreams of building a permanent house for his family and expand his farming activities.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a water pump and 3 gallons of petrol.

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap C. is a villager in Kou Chen Leaeng village in Takeo province. She owns a small grocery store in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery goods for her business. Her husband, Mr. Hong Sambo, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. This couple has five children, two of whom are working in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods for her business.

loans.name: Michael Kazungu

texts.en:
Michael Kazungu M. is a 34-year old farmer who lives in Malindi and is married to Janet Kangombe. They have five children between the ages of 11 years and 9 months.

Michael has been in the farming business for the last five years. He was introduced to KADET by an agricultural officer in Malindi. With this loan, Michael plans to pay for farm labor and to buy petrol, farm seedlings, and pesticides. He intends to open his own farm store to sell supplies directly to farmers. (Currently, the farmers buy supplies from brokers.)

He also dreams of building his own hardware shop and describes himself as quiet, focused, and hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.name: Agnes Kadzo

texts.en:
Agnes Kadzo S. is 32 years old and lives in Malindi with her husband, S. Karisa. They have five children between the ages of 17 and 6.

Agnes has been a farmer for the last twelve years. She was introduced to KADET by a group cordinator in the area. With this loan, she plans to buy a water pump to boost her produce.

With the profits from the improved earnings of her farm, Agnes hopes to educate her children comfortably. She also dreams of building rental houses and buying a posho mill (a mill that grinds wheat or maize into flour) so as to ensure high standards of living for her family.

Agnes describes herself as very diligent and hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. loans.use: To purchase a water pump to improve her farm's production.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie D. is from the village of Colupan, Bajo, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Rosalie owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 1,600 PHP a month. In 2008, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Angie

texts.en:
Angie B. is from the village of Colupan Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 19 years old. Angie is single. 

To make a living, Angie owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling electronic loads, which are devices used to test electronic circuits for items like power supplies, batteries, solar and fuel cells, and generators. Angie has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Angie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angie is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Khom

texts.en:
Mrs. Khom M. is a villager in Ta Koem village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 0.8-hectare field of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. El Nop, is a Khmer cheese seller who can make a little income to support the family. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than is needed to support the family.

In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Khom M. is applying a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Khom M. is a mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Eunice Tabu

texts.en:
Eunice Tabu K. is 32 years and married to Kasena Baya. Together they have six children between the ages of 2 and 16. They live in Malindi.

Eunice has been in the farming business for 12 years. She earns a monthly profit of 2,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from farming. She plans to use the loan to purchase maize seedlings, fertilizers, and pesticides in order to boost her crop output. With the extra earnings she hopes to purchase a water pump.

Eunice describes herself as hardworking and dreams of building a lovely, fully furnished family home.

loans.name: James Elly

texts.en:
James is 37 years and married to Loice Kadzo. The couple has six children, aged between 13 years and six months.

James has been in farming for the last 10 years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 2000. He was introduced to Kadet by one of the members in his group. Through this loan, he hopes to expand his farming business and employ others. He will use the loan specifically to buy seeds, pesticides, petrol, fertilizers and labor for his business.

James describes himself as a progressive client who always seeks ways to move forward. His ambition is to save and educate his children to university level and build rental houses to increase his income.

About KADET:

Mrs. Phan O. lives in Daeum Rumdael village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 0.5-hectare field to cultivate rice. She is facing a small problem because her field is infertile, so she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field. She would use the rest of the loan to buy a cow for breeding.

She hopes to increase their income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Phon Mem, is a construction worker. Mrs. Phan O. is the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another one is a construction worker. The others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:

To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Wilma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: K. Philomène est née en 1967 à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Philomène est mariée à DANSI Mathieu, un cultivateur. Le couple a cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C'est depuis 16 ans que Philomène vit à Sèmè-Podji avec ses enfants et son mari. Philomène vient en aide à son mari Mathieu dans les charges de la famille. Philomène n'a jamais été à l'école. Cela fait déjà 20 ans que Philomène vend des produits vivriers (riz, maïs, etc.) à son domicile. Philomène s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une cliente de ALIDé qui a reçu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et qui l'a bien remboursé. Afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'agrandir davantage son activité, Philomène sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Philomène was born in 1967 in Ekpè, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. Philomène is married to Dansi Mathieu, un farmer. The oucple has 5 children, all of whom are students. For the last 16 years, Philomène has lived in Sèmè-Podji with her children and husband. Philomène helps her husband, Mathieu, pay for the family expenses. Philomène never attended school. For the past 20 years, Philomène has sold foodstuffs (rice, corn, etc.) from her home. Philomène supplies herself in Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She is a client of ALIDé and has received one loan from ALIDé, which has been fully repaid. In order to grow her business' funds and expand the business itself, Philomène is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs (sacks of rice and corn)

They face a problem because the field is infertile. Mrs. Phal H. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to support the rice field, in order to make it more productive. She has three children who are all enrolled in the local school.

loans.name: Idersaikhan

texts.en:
S. Idersaikhan is 35 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His oldest two sons attend a local secondary school and his youngest daughter is in kindergarten.

Idersaikhan operates a raw materials trading business in his town. He started selling raw materials in 2007 after trading consumer goods for the previous seven years. Idersaikhan has made quick progress with his raw materials business and has built a good reputation among both his customers and suppliers. His earnings have enabled him to purchase a car for his family, and today his working captial exceeds 4,000,000 tugrugs (~3000 USD).

Idersaikhan is very decent person who works hard to achieve his goals no matter how difficult they might be. He says, "My business goal is to supply quality products to the market." He is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2500 USD) loan to purchase more raw materials to sell in his business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials

loans.name: Asucina

texts.en:
Asucina B. is from the village of Balanlinao. She is 44 years old. Asucina is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Asucina owns & operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing & selling products to local businesses and community members. Asucina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Asucina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asucina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Asucina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 13th loan taken out by Asucina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Baet

texts.en: Mrs. Baet I. lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Since her business is goI. well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food. Her husband, Mr. Nom Meiy, is a farmer. Mrs. Baet I. is the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another one is a farmer. The youngest one is attendI. the local school.

loans.use: to buy more piglets for breeding and food for them

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Composé d’une veuve et de trois femmes mariées, les membres du groupe Badenya ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles conjugales nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux dans le quartier Massabla-coura de la ville de Bougouni (3eme région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des relations de commerce. Elles font le commerce de bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois et bien d’autres articles divers.  
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur ressource financière et de faire assez de stocks enfin de satisfaire le besoin de la clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt de groupe et tous les six prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 20 tonnes de bois de chauffe et 15 tonnes de charbon de bois. Les produits seront achetés auprès des fournisseurs des villages environnants de Bougouni pour être ensuite revendus dans la ville de Bougouni. 
La vente se fait au comptant et en détail à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé comme frais de santé et d’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Composed of a widow and three married women, the members of this Badenya group have an average age of 34, 4 children on average each, and live in nuclear families with their husbands and children, in the Massabla-coura district of the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They met through their businesses. They sell firewood, charcoal, and various other items. With the intention of increasing their working capital and stocking up so that they can satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their 7th group loan, with all the 6 preceding loans correctly reimbursed.

With this new loan they intend to buy 20 tons of firewood and 15 tons of charcoal. The goods are bought from suppliers from the villages surrounding Bougouni and are then sold in the town of Bougouni.

Sales are made for cash and retail to a clientele composed of men and women. With this loan, the group members hope each one to make a monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which will be used to pay expenses for the health and education of their children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Chamreourn

texts.en: Mrs. Chamreourn S. lives in Cheung Prey Bei village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a 0.5-hectare field of land to cultivate rice. She is also breeding pigs at her house. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Khan Kheourn, helps her with the current business. Mrs. Chamreourn S. has five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy more piglets for breeding.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Balimaya est composé exclusivement de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans,  7 enfants et qui  vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Elles résident toutes dans le quartier Dialanikoro de la ville de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de voisinage et de commerce. Elles font essentiellement le commerce des chaussures et d’habits.
Avec l’idée de fournir aux clients des produits de meilleures qualités et de faire assez de stocks, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le précédent a été bien remboursé. 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 500 paires de chaussures de qualité différentes. Les chaussures sont achetées auprès des grossistes sur le marché de Bamako pour être  revendues ensuite dans le grand marché Bougouni. La vente se fait en détail au comptant ou à crédit. Leur clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA par mois qui sera réutilisé  dans leur activité.
texts.en:
This Balimaya group is made up exclusively of married women whose average age is 37, with 7 children on average, and who live in traditional polygamous families with their brothers, sisters, co-spouses, children, and husbands. They all live in the Dialanikoro neighborhood of the town of Bougouni, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

These women met because of being neighbors and through their businesses. They essentially sell shoes and clothing. With the idea of offering their clients better quality products and being able to stock up, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second group loan with the first correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they intend to buy 500 pairs of shoes of various kinds. The shoes are bought from wholesalers in the markets at Bamako to be sold in the big open-air market of Bougouni. Sales are made retail, for cash or credit. Their clientele is composed of men and women. With this loan each of the group members hopes to make a monthly profit of 25,000 F CFA which will be reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio C. is from the village of Cabol-anonan, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. He is 70 years old. Rogelio is married and has 7 adult children. 

In 2008, Rogelio joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation.  Rogelio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to for house repair. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to finish the house repair. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rogelio from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make further improvements to his house.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia T. is from the village of Barangay Uno. She is 33 years old. Sonia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Sonia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and support the education of her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Lorie

texts.en:
Lorie D. is from the village of Curvada, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 46 years old. Lorie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Lorie owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling rice and daily-use products like shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Lorie has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Lorie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorie successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lorie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Lorie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and pay the tuition of her two children.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Munkhtsog

texts.en:
Munkhtsog is 48 years old and lives with his wife and three of his four children in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son has joined the army, and the youngest two attend a local secondary school.

Munkhtsog runs a meat trading business with his wife in their town. He began his business in 1995 and since then has been able to purchase a truck and start a second business, a transportation service. Since beginning his second business, his wife is in charge of the meat trading business while Munkhtsog is in charge of the transportation business. He is requesting a 250,000 tugrug (~170 USD) loan in order to purchase livestock in order to sell their raw materials.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en: Mrs. Chantha K. lives in Vihear village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Since her poultry business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more ducks to breed. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Vong Seourn, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Chantha K. is the mother of six children, one of whom is a laborer while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to breed.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont tous des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles conjugales nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le quartier Dialanikoro de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des relations de mariage et font le commerce  d’articles d’occasion (habits, chaussures, sacs etc).
Dans le souci d’acheter assez de balles de friperie pour augmenter leurs stocks, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe et les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau  prêt elles comptent acheter, 9 balles de friperie sur le marché de Bamako pour ensuite les revendre dans le marché de Bougouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Les produits sont vendus en détail au comptant ou à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 45 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux frais d’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The members of the group Danaya are married women averaging 28 years of age and 3 children each living in conjugal nuclear families with their children and husbands. These women reside in the Dialanikoro district of the city of  Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of marriage, and they do commerce in second-hand goods (clothing, shoes, bags, etc.)  Concerned about buying enough bales of used items to augment their stocks, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their fifth group loan.  The preceding ones have been properly repaid.  With this new loan, they intend to buy 9 bales of used clothing and the like at the Bamako market.  And then they will sell them at the Bougouni market to customers composed of women and men.  The goods are sold retail in cash transactions or on credit. With this loan, the group members each plan on realizing a profit of 45,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to cover the costs of educating the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Second-hand clothing

loans.name: Mahuna Léah

texts.fr: B. Mahuna Léah est née en 1959 à Adjohoun dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin. Mahuna Léah est mariée à AVLESSI Abraham et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Mahuna Léah vit depuis 20 ans à Agbalilamè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, avec son mari et ses enfants. Mahuna Léah supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Mahuna Léah mène comme activité, la vente de divers (pâtes alimentaires, savons, lait, sucre, piles, sardines, bougies, etc.) et aussi de l'huile végétale et du riz à son domicile. C'est à Adja au Mono, et à Ikpinlè, au Bénin, que Mahuna Léah s'approvisionne. Il y a 19 ans de cela que Mahuna Léah mène cette activité. Mahuna Léah est une cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien. C'est dans l'optique de renforcer le stock de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, que Mahuna Léah sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
B. Mahuna Léah was born in 1959, in Adjouhoun within the county of Ouémé in Benin. Mahuna Léah is married to Avlessi Abraham and is the mother of 4 children, all of whom attend school. For the past 20 years, Mahuna Léah has lived in Agbalilamè, in the county of Sèmè-Podji, with her husband and their children. With her husband, Mahuna Léah provides for her families needs and expenses. To pay for her needs and those of her children, Mahuna Léah has a business selling a variety of goods (pasta, soaps, milk, sugar, batteries, sardines, candles, etc.), vegetable oil and rice from her home. Mahuna Léah supplies herself in Adja (in Mono) and in Ikpinlè (in Bénin). Mahuna Léah has run this business for 19 years. Mahuna Léah is a client of ALIDé and has properly repaid previous loans. In order to re-stock her products and better satisfy her clientele, Mahuna Léah is requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 50 containers of vegetable oil

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel R. is from the village of Balanlinao. She is 32 years old. Maricel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maricel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand product offering. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Maricel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Nen

texts.en: Mrs. Nen C. lives in Ping Pong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to support the rice field. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and rice seed. Her husband, Mr. Chhay Theourn, is a laborer who makes a small income to support the family. Mrs. Nen C. is the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school, while the other is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and rice seed.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Tous mariés, les membres du groupe Djiguiya ont en moyenne 34 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec les frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le quartier Massabla-coura de la ville de Bougouni dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des relations de mariages et de commerce de céréales. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur ressource financière afin de faire assez de stocks de céréales, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 6 tonnes de maïs, 500kg de fonio et 3 tonnes de petit mil. Les produits sont achetés auprès des fournisseurs des villages environnants de Bougouni pour être  ensuite revendus en gros sur le marché de Bamako. Leur clientèle est essentiellement composée d’hommes et la vente se fait au comptant. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes envisagent obtenir chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé selon elles dans leur activité.
texts.en:
All married, the members of the Djiguiya group are, on average, 34-years-old and have 5 children. They live in traditional domestic families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children, and husbands. These women live in the Massabla-coura section of Bougouni village in the third administrative region of Mali. They know each other through marriage and the grain trade. In order to stock grain and increase their financial resources, they have decided to join together at the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. As a group, they are on their sixth loan; they successfully repaid their first five loans. With this loan, they intend to buy 6 tons of corn, 500 kg of fonio (a West African grain), and 3 tons of millet. They purchase the products from suppliers in villages surrounding Bougouni and then resell them at retail prices at the Bamako market. Their customers are primarily men, and sales are made in cash. With this loan, the women each envision receiving a monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA to be used depending on each woman's individual activities.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Grains

loans.name: Roath

texts.en:
Mr. Roath N. lives in Rung Village in Kandal Province. He and his wife, Mrs. Pring Sinoeurn, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. They are the parents of one child who is too young to work or study.

On their farm, they face some problems because they need some money to buy rice seed, pesticides, and to fund plowing on the rice field. Thus, Mr. Roath N. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, pesticides, and to fund plowing on the rice field.

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabali est composé de femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 26 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux et résident dans le quartier Massabla-coura de la ville de Bougouni qui relève de la 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des relations de commerce et essentiellement du commerce de condiments alimentaires. 
Dans l’intention de développer leur commerce en se constituant plus de stocks enfin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 20boites de 2kg de concentrée de tomate, 8 sacs de 25kg de sel de cuisine, 15 paquets de 100 morceaux de cube maggi et diverses autres qualités de condiments alimentaires. 
Les produits sont achetés auprès des grossistes de Bamako pour être revendus ensuite en détail dans le marché de Bougouni. Leur clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes et les condiments sont vendus au comptant ou à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes envisagent obtenir chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA par mois qui sera réutilisé dans leur activité.
texts.en:
This Sabali group is composed of married women who have an average age of 26 and on average, 2 children. They live in nuclear families with their children and spouses in the Massabla-Coura neighborhood of the town of Bougouni which comes under the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

These women met through their businesses; they all essentially sell condiments. In the intention of developing their businesses and stocking up so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second group loan; the preceding loan was correctly reimbursed.

With this loan, they intend to buy 20 tins of 2 kg each of tomato paste, 8 sacks of 25 kg of cooking salt, 15 packs of 100 individual Maggi cubes, and various other condiments. The products are bought from wholesalers in Bamako and are sold retail in the market at Bougouni. Their clientele is essentially composed of women, and the condiments are sold for cash or on credit. Each of the women expects to make a monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA with this loan. The profit will be reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for resale

loans.name: Bros

texts.en:
Mr. Bros N. is a villager in Rung Village in Takeo Province.  He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  His wife, Mrs. N. Nub, helps him on the farm. He is the father of two children, a garment factory worker and a student at a local school.

Mr. Bros N. faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to buy rice seed, pesticides, and fertilizers to support a productive farm. Thus, he decided to request a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, pesticides, and fertilizers.

loans.name: Hishgee

texts.en:
Hishgee is 58 years old and lives with her husband and 22-year-old son in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. With the help of her husband, Hishgee operates a raw material trading business in their town; she specializes in sheep and goat skins. She began her business in 2009 after managing a meat retail business in their town for six years.

Hishgee and her husband have much experience and hope to keep growing their raw material business in the future. Hishgee is requesting a 1,680,000 tugrug (~1200 USD) loan in order to purchase sheep and goat skins for her business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and goat skins

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohmmad is a young single man; he owns a shop in a very busy location in the old city of Bethlehem.

Mohammad started with vegetable kiosk (since his father also owns a vegetable shop) when he was very young and from the income of this kiosk, a year ago he started a partnership with one of his friends in this shop where he sells cosmetics, perfumes, accessories, scarves.....the shop is managed by both Mohammad and his friend, and Mohammad still has his vegetable kiosk next to this shop.

Mohammad is a very ambitious young man. He hopes that he will be able to have good source of income from these two businesses and ultimately will start his own family.

Mohammad requested 2000 USD from Faten to buy some products for his shop as it is Eid Al-Adha next week and the demand for his products became greater. Mohammad appears in the picture at his business.

loans.use: Buy products for the shop

loans.name: Marites

Marites M. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Marites is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marites joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Marites is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marites from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarin N. lives in Chong Angkar village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2.5 hectare field to cultivate rice. She faces an obstacle with her plantation because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers and pesticides to support the crop. She decided to ask for a loan to buy these for her farm. Her husband, Mr. Pin Sophat, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Sarin N. has two children who are also farmers. 
Her husband is present on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Renevic

texts.en:
Renevic P. is from the village of  San Andres, Kadingilan,  Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Renevic is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Renevic runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Renevic has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Renevic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Renevic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Renevic is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Renevic from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Algaa

texts.en:
Algaa is a widower who lives in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He lives alone in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and operates a religious goods retail business in his town. He began his business in 2007 with working capital of 250,000 tugrugs (about $170) and with several years of hard work, he has managed to increase his working capital to exceed 1,200,000 tugrugs (about $840). With the success of his business, he has managed to purchase a car and establish himself in the business community. Algaa is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of religious goods for his business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.
