loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun U. is a villager in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5 hectare field of land to cultivate rice for a living. She faces an obstacle with her plantation because her field has infertile soil; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to bU. fertilizers and pesticides for her crop. Her husband, Mr. Yu Sareourn, makes big pots to sell. This couple has two children: one attends the local school and the younger one is too young to work or study. 
Her husband is present on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides for her crop

loans.name: Nicole

texts.fr: D. S. Nicole est née en 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Nicole est mariée à AHOUANSOU Gilles, un revendeur. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. C'est depuis sept ans que Nicole vit à Djeffa, dans la commune D. Sèmè-Podji, avec ses enfants et son mari. Nicole vient en aiD. à son mari dans les charges D. la famille. Nicole a fait seulement le cours primaire. Depuis 5 ans, Nicole mène comme activité, la vente D. produits D. beauté et des ustensiles D. cuisine (plastiques, plats, etc.)D. façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Nicole fait ses approvisionnements. Nicole a déjà obtenu une fois D. crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Afin D. renforcer son activité et D. mieux satisfaire la demanD. D. plus en plus nombreuse D. sa clientèle, Nicole sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès D. ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. S. Nicole was born in 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Nicole is married to Ahouansou Gilles, a re-seller. The couple has 3 children, some of whom are attending school. For the past 7 years, Nicole has lived in Djeffa, in the county of Sèmè-Podji, with her children and husband. Nicole helps her husband pay for the family's expenses. Nicole only attended primary school. For 5 years, Nicole has run this business, selling cosmetics and kitchen utensils (plastic buckets, dishes, etc.); she sells as she walks around town. Nicole supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Nicole has previously had one loan from ALIDé, which she fully repaid. In order to improve her business and better satisfy the growing needs of her clientele, Nicole is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beauty products/ cosmetics (body lotion, face creams, perfumes etc.)

loans.name: Everlie

texts.en:
Everlie G. is from the village of Centro Napu, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Everlie is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Everlie owns & operates a retail clothing store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Everlie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Everlie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Everlie is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Everlie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Kunthea I. is a villager I. Tuol Kandal village I. Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. She now faces a small problem with this farming because her field has infertile soil. She is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides and to plow the field. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's standard of living with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Yang Sdeng, is a fisherman who catches a few fish to support the family. Mrs. Kunthea I. is the mother of two children who attend the local school. 
Her husband is on the right I. the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides and to plow the field

loans.name: Vandanduger

texts.en:
Vandanduger is 28 years old and lives with his wife and 2-year-old child in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His child is in daycare, and his wife is a teacher at a local secondary school.

Vandanduger operates a raw materials trading business in town. He began his business in 2007 after managing a consumer goods retail business for 7 years. When he began his raw material business, his working capital was 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD) and in just over two years operation, his working capital has grown to exceed 3,600,000 tugrugs (~2570 USD). In order to supplement his family’s income, Vandanduger operates a taxi service at night.

Vandanduger is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2500 USD) loan in order to purchase more quality raw materials for his business. He hopes to be able to provide his family with a comfortable life while providing his local market with quality raw materials.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more quality raw materials

loans.name: Mariesol

texts.en:
Mariesol S. is from the village of San Andres , Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Mariesol is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mariesol owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready-to-wear items such as shirts and blouses to local community members. Mariesol has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mariesol joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mariesol successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Mariesol is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Mariesol from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Dorl

texts.en: Mr. Dorl K. is a villager in Thmei village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this activity, he is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and feed. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living conditions with this loan. His wife, Mrs. Cheom Mom, helps him in the business. Mr. Dorl K. is a father of seven children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the others attend the local school. His wife is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and feed

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
Myagmarsuren is 31 years old and lives with his 9-year-old daughter in the province of Khovd in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife must stay at home due to a disability and his daughter attends a local secondary school.

Myagmarsuren operates a transportation service in his town. He transports coal and firewood to the local residents. He began his business in 2001 and since then, he has expanded and grown his business steadily. Firewood and coal are the main home heating fuels in Mongolia and transporting them to the soums and villages is an important service.

In the future, he is planning to purchase a new truck and grow vegetables so that he can sell them at the local market for extra income. He says, “I have planted a small number of vegetables in past years and I am planning on planting a larger number of vegetables next year.” Myagmarsuren is requesting a 1,100,000 tugrug (~770 USD) loan in order to purchase replacement parts for his truck so that he can continue delivering firewood and coal this winter.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase replacement parts for his truck

loans.name: Norn

texts.en: Mrs. Norn P. is a villager in Klaong Tvear village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more ducks and duck food to increase their breeding. Mrs. Norn P. is a widow with three children, two of whom are laborers, while the youngest one is enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more ducks and duck food

loans.name: Mohammad Hasham Ameir Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Marzya is the group leader of M. H. Ameir M. group. There are six members in this group. Marzya is 48 years old and married with five children, three daughters and two sons. They are in school. She wants to take a loan to improve her husband’s business, a fuel selling shop.

Sameyna and Zaynab want to take a loan for their home-based business of carpet weaving. They need a loan for their business to progress. Safya and Shakyllah want to take a loan for their husbands' shared business of a general store and vegetable selling. Both women clean and package the vegetables, and then their husbands sell them in their shop. They want to expand their business. And Saleha wants to take a loan for her husband, who has a car part shop. He wants to make his shop larger. 

They requested a group loan of 60,000 Afghani. With this loan they can make their businesses larger, support their families and make a better future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: To expand their businesses, such as fuel sales

loans.name: Ngoem

texts.en: Mrs. Ngoem S. is a villager in Srae Vong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 2.5 hectares to cultivate rice to earn a living. She now faces a problem in this farming because she does not have enough rice seeds. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice seeds for her farming. Her husband, Mr. Tes Muth, is a salt middleman. Mrs. Ngoem S. is a mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others work as laborers in Thailand. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more rice seeds for her farming

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marialie

texts.en:
Marialie B. is from the village of Salvacion , Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 31 years old. Marialie is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Marialie owns and operates a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Marialie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marialie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marialie successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. Marialie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Marialie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Sokhoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhoeurn V. is a villager in Prey Run village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 0.70-hectare field to cultivate rice. She is also a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig food. She would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer to support the field. Mrs. Sokhoeurn V. is a widow with two children who are both enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig food and fertilizer

loans.name: Davaahuu

texts.en:
Davaahuu N. is 44 years old and the mother of two girls and two boys. She currently lives with her husband and four children in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. Her two oldest children are 22 and 21 years old, and they currently pursue their small businesses. The 18-year-old daughter is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and the youngest child is a 14-year-old daughter who is a secondary school student.

Davaahuu sells various animal skins and hides at the local black market. She purchases sheep, goat, and cattle skins and hides from herder families in the countryside and sell them at the market at a premium. She has been in the business since 1998. Last year, her business was affected by the price drop in the commodities market due to the economic crisis in Mongolia. She says that the business is starting to pick up and the demand for commodities is slowing recovering. Thus, she requests a loan to purchase more animal skins for her business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase more animal skin

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom T. is a villager in Srae Vong village in Takeo province.She is a widow with two children, one of whom attends the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Sarom T. is a clothes seller in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more clothes to re-sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to re-sell.

loans.name: Shurenchimeg

texts.en:
Shurenchimeg D. is 37 years-old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanhongor province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. Her two sons are 12 and 18 years old and go to a local secondary school. Shurenchimeg and her family used to be herders but moved to their current town a few years ago after losing much of their livestock in a harsh winter. She now works as a sewer and makes various traditional clothes for locals. She is a talented sewer who learned about making traditional clothes from her mother. She has been making traditional clothes since her family moved in 2006. With the business profits, she has been able to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband and his business. She says that she works hard to set aside some money to purchase a piece of land where she can live with her family in peace because her family currently lives on someone else's land which causes strains.

Shurenchimeg would like a loan to purchase cotton, silk and other necessary materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: B. Véronique est née le 05 Juillet 1971 à Adjohoun dans le département de l'Ouémé, au Bénin. Véronique est mariée à FONTECLOUNON Cyril, un carroleur. Le couple a deux enfants. Mais en plus de ces enfants, un autre enfant est à leur charge. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. C'est depuis 13 ans que la famille vit à PK10 Bahocon, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Véronique a très peu fréquenté l'école. Il y a 10 ans de cela que Véronique vend des liqueurs de tous genres, des divers (fournitures scolaires, papiers mouchoirs, lait, poudre, défrisants, coton, etc.) et de l'huile végétale dans sa boutique sise au bord de la von Bahocon dans son quartier. Véronique s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Véronique sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d'augmenter son capital et de renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
B. Véronique was born on the 5th of July, 1971, in Adjohoun, in the county of Ouémé, in Bénin. Véronique is married to Fonteclounon Cyril, a mason. The couple has 2 children. In addition to their 2 children, they also care for one other child. Some of the children are attending school. For the past 13 years, the family has lived in PK10 Bahocon, in the county of Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. Together, the couple takes care of their family's expenses. Véronique attended very little school. For the past 10 years, Véronique has been selling a variety of liquors, various items (school supplies, paper handkerchiefs, milk, powder, straightening balm, cotton etc.) and vegetable oil, in her store located on the border of Bahocon, in her neighborhood. Véronique supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. This is the first time that Véronique has requested a loan from ALIDé; she is requesting the loan in order to grow her capital and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase liquor, straightening balm, vegetable oil, paper napkins, milk

loans.name: Annalyn

texts.en:
Annalyn B. is from the village of Bocboc, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 23 years-old and married with three school-aged children. Annalyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Annalyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Annalyn joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Annalyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Annalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Khader

texts.en:
Khader is a young Palestinian man living in Bethlehem city. He has a small kiosk (stand) in the old city of Bethlehem at the vegetable & fruit market. Khader started this business 10 years ago when he was very young and he gained experience when he was even younger as his father also owns a vegetable and fruit shop and he used to help him.

Khader requested 2000 USD from FATEN to buy a large quantity of fruits and vegetables for Eid Al-Adha (a Muslim feast day), as wholesale merchants in such events request cash for providing the merchandise, especially since it becomes more expensive on such occasions. Also there is high demand next month as Christmas and New Year are coming in late December for Western Christians and early January for Eastern Christians.

Khader is still single and he hopes that very soon he will be economically independent and can afford the expected expenses of having a family. Khader appears in the picture at his business.

loans.use: Buy products for his vegetable and fruit kiosk

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en:
Oyun-Erdene D. is 47 years-old and lives with her mother and 26-year-old son in Tuv province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She has a small-scale food store in the town. Her mother is the cashier and they mostly sell basic food products such as rice, floor and beverages such as soft-drinks. She purchases food products from wholesale markets in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and sells them through her store. She pays a visit to Ulaanbaatar 4-5 times per month to purchase the inventory for her business. She has been running the store with help from her mother since 2004 and they have been quite successful. She says that she would like to expand her store by adding a greater variety of food products.  She requests a loan to purchase more food products for her business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

loans.use: To purchase more food products .

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa T. is from the village of Unidos. She is 65 years old. Narcisa is widowed and has 4 adult children. Narcisa has a general store from which she sells a variety of products to the local community. Narcisa has been in business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (about $32 US) a month for these activities.

In 1999, Narcisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business.  Narcisa is requesting a loan of 10,000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital.  This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Narcisa from PMPC. Narcisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 pesos from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Ricky

texts.en:
Ricky B. is from the village of Damulog, Bukidnon. He is 34 years-old and married with three school-aged children. Ricky owns and operates a business making and selling designed walls made of bamboo materials. These are usually used as walls or siding of cottages or even houses in the local community. Ricky has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ricky joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ricky has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Ricky is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ricky from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. p> *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: O. Véronique est née le 10 Juin 1963 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNGAVOU Ernest un chauffeur, Véronique est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Véronique vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin, depuis 5 ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Véronique n'a pas été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Véronique vend des fagots de bois et aussi du charbon de bois à son domicile. C'est depuis cinq ans que Véronique mène cette activité. Véronique s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Véronique sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
O. Véronique was born on June 10th, 1963 in Porto-Novo, the governmental capital of Benin. Véronique is married to Houngavou Ernest, who is a driver. Véronique is the mother of three children, all of whom are attending school. For the past 5 years, Véronique has lived with her children and husband in Djeffa, in the district of Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. Together the couple pays for their family's expenses. Véronique did not attend school. To provide for her family's needs, Véronique sells bundles of sticks of wood and coal from her home. Véronique has run this business for the past 5 years. Véronique supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. This is the first time that Véronique has requested a loan from ALIDé, she is requesting the loan in order to grow the funds for her business and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood in bulk

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita T. lives in the village of Talusan, Brgy. Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She is 56 years-old and married to Romeo who is a 59 year-old fisherman. They have ten children whose ages range from 14 to 36 years-old. The older ones have their own jobs and help their parents support the family, while the younger ones still attend school. Purita works hard to help her husband earn additional income to support their family of 12. She dreams that all of her children will finish their studies and have a good job.

Just like other wives who help their husbands support their family, Purita looked for ways to add on to their capital. In 1998, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could have access to capital so that they could buy additional fishing gear and equipment. Later, she and her husband realized that instead of selling the catch to a local vendor wholesale, they could earn more if Purita sold their catch to the community on a retail basis. This decision turned out to be a good idea as it also enabled them to develop good relationships with their regular customers. Now she earns a minimum of Php 6,000 per month from her business activities.

In her last loan she borrowed Php 19,500 as additional working capital for her fishing business. After repaying that loan she now wants to borrow the same amount of PhP 19,500 for her 10th cycle loan to be used to purchase a new fishing boat.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a new fishing boat.

loans.name: T. Ella

texts.fr: A. T. Ella est née le 05 Février 1983 et est mariée à HOUNVO Sètondji, un boucher. Le couple n'a pas encore d'enfant, mais ont trois enfants à charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. C'est depuis 10 ans que Ella vit avec sa famille au quartier Jésuko à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Ella vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Ella n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a dix ans déjà que Ella vend des chaussures et des sacs de sortie de façon ambulante et par le système de distribution. Ella s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Ella sollicite de crédit auprès de ALIDé. C'est pour renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle que Ella sollicite ce premier crédit.
texts.en:
A. T. Ella was born February 5th, 1983 and is married to Hounvo Sètondji, a butcher. The couple has not yet had children, but they care for three children. All of the children are attending school. For the past ten years, Ella has lived with her family in the neighborhood of Jésuko in Ekpè, in the district of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Ella helps her husband pay for the family's expenses. Ella did not attend school. For the past ten years, Ella has sold shoes and bags by walking around and through a distribution system. She supplies herself in Lomé, which is in Togo, the country next to Benin. This is the first time that Ella has requested a loan from ALIDé. In order to strengthen her business and better satisfy her clientele, Ella is requesting her first loan.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes and bags for women

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura G. was born in 1959 in Koti village, Ijevan area. She is a widow and has four daughters. Two of them are married and live separately from Laura. Laura was a cigarette maker in the state farm for about 18 years. Since 1990, she is engaged in cattle breeding and land cultivation. Thanks to her income Laura provides for her family needs, organized her two daughters’ weddings and paid for their educations.

Laura needs a loan of 500,000 AMD to buy pigs and fodder for her farm animals. She plans to spend her increased income on her younger daughters’ educations and to provide a dowry for them.

loans.use: To buy pigs and fodder.

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi is 36 years-old and married with four children. She sells used hand bags. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a hardworking woman and she makes sure she has food on the table everyday through her hard work. Ngozi is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more used hand bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase used hand bags.

loans.name: Laure

texts.fr: D. Laure est née en 1969 et est mariée et mère de 8 enfants, dont 4 sont à sa charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Laure vit avec son mari et ses enfants à PK11 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji depuis près de 9 ans. Laure vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Laure a seulement fait le cours primaire à l'école. Il y de cela deux ans que Laure mène comme activité, la vente de chaussures et aussi des sacs de sortie, par le système de distribution. Laure s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Laure sollicite de crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face aux demandes de la clientèle.
texts.en:
D. Laure was born in 1969, she is married and the mother of 8 children, 4 of whom are currently in her care. All of the children attend school. Laure has lived with her husband and their children in PK11, in the district of Sèmè-Podji. Laure helps her husband pay for her family's expenses. Laure only attended primary school. For the past two years, Laure has run this business, selling shoes and handbags through her distribution system. Laure supplies herself in Lomé (within Togo, Benin's neighboring country) and also from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. This is the first time Laure has requested a loan from ALIDé. She is requesting the loan in order to strengthen her business and better handle the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes and bags for women

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Wali Zada Sartapa Group

texts.en:
This is the WA. Zada Sartapa group. Its four members live in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. They all would like to take a loan for their business progress. They have totally requested a group loan of 56000 Afghani.

Ghulam Sakhi, the group leader, has a shop selling vegetables. With the loan he would progress his business and buy more vegetables to have more clients.

Mushtaq is a taxi driver. He daily works hard to support his family members with the income he receives. Now he has a problem with the old machine of his taxi, so he wants to take a loan to buy a new machine for his taxi to work in a better way.

Aziza is a tailor. She sews different kinds of clothes and with her income she supports her husband and children.

The last member of this group is Nasima who is a baker. She has a bakery in her house and all her neighbors are her clients who come to her bakery and ask her to bake bread. With the loan she wants to buy more materials and wood.

They are all thankful to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Expanding their  businesses.

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en:
Theresia is 59 years-old and married with four adult children and two grandchildren. She runs Theresia Ladies Fashion where she makes and sells wedding dresses. She has been in business for 24 years and has two employees. She also earns some income through small-scale farming of maize and beans.

Theresia has successfully completed a previous loan for Kes. 80,000 and is requesting another loan for the same amount from Kiva partner Faulu to buy more material for wedding dresses. She hopes to generate more income so that she can better provide for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric.

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en: Maureen is excited to take her first loan with Kiva. She will use this loan to invest in a business selling textile materials which she will buy in bulk to get a better price. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family. She is married with three children and she is 41 years-old. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more textile materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase textiles.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is 40 years-old and married with four children, two of whom are attending school. He runs a computer shop in Kitengela, a small town near Nairobi. He provides photocopying, typesetting and design services in his shop and is in his fourth year of business. He also earns some extra income keeping livestock. He describes himself as humble, focused, and self-motivated.  He has requested this loan of Kes. 40,000 from Kiva partner Faulu to install Internet connectivity in his shop. In the future, he hopes to be a leading service provider in the area, have good equipment and offer efficient service.

loans.use: To install internet.

loans.name: Sundur

texts.en:
A. Sundur is 39 years old. He learned his profession of cattle farming from his father when he was young. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and seeing his family progressing more and more. In addition to raising animals, Sundur also runs a taxi driver service in his free times.

With his previous loans, Sundur purchased one cattle. He sold it already and purchased two young calves, which he is rearing to sell. Today he wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. From the profit of his business, Sundur wants to educate his children at the university in the future. With your help this will be possible.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase small cattle

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth sells sarongs in the market. She is married with 4 children and she is 39 years old.

Ruth hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase a variety of clothing items to significantly expand her clothing trade. Ruth believes that having an assortment of women's outerwear that is both practical and good quality will increase her sales and offer both warmth and style suitable to any taste and weather.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Raed

texts.en:
Raed is married with four children.  He has been working as a taxi driver for a long time as he left school before finishing his high school.  He was not a hard working student, even hough his father was the principle, because he always preferred the freedom of working. 

Raed owns a van that works between Hebron, Beit Ummar village, and Bethlehem.  His work is going very well, last year he bought a new van in exchange for the old van and all his savings. Since he spent his savings to buy the new van, Raed is requesting a loan from FATEN for $1500 US to pay insurance and registration fees.  He must pay these to be able to register the new van, which is required before he can use it for work.

Raed appears in the picture next to his van.

loans.use: Registration & insurance fees

loans.name: Rahmat

texts.en:
At 49 years of age, Rahmat is married and has three children. His principal work is the buying and selling of cattle. This business requires lots of travel because he needs to go to remote areas where these animals cost less. This requires considerable financial means. The business is very profitable, but his lack of capital makes his income insignificant, and living conditions remain difficult in his household.

To strengthen his business, Rahmat is asking for a loan of $1000 USD, which he will use to buy more cattle for expanding his business. This will allow him to meet the needs of his household effectively.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase small cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Léa

texts.fr: S. Léa est née en 1971 et est mariée à HOUNSOU Philippe, un mécanicien. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont à leur charge. La famille vit à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis 13 ans. Léa vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la maison. Léa n'a pas été à l'école, mais a appris la couture. En plus de ce métier, Léa a une cabine téléphonique et vend également des cartes de recharges téléphoniques et des articles de mercerie à Ekpè. Cela fait trois ans que Léa mène cette activité. Léa s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et la taille de son activité, Léa sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Léa was born in 1971 and is married to Hounsou Philippe, a mechanic. The couple has six children, all of whom attend school, four of whom are currently in the couple's care. For the past 13 years, the family has lived in Ekpè, in the district of Sèmè-Podji. Léa helps her husband pay for their family's expenses. Léa did not attend school, but learned sewing. In addition to this trade, Léa has a phone booth, sells refill cards of phone credit and also sells a variety of goods for dressmaking in Ekpè. Léa has had this business for the past 3 years. Léa supplies herself in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a client of ALIDé and has already received one loan, which was fully repaid. In order to grow her business' funds and the size of her business, Léa is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dressmaking materials and phone recharge cards

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is fifty-five years old. She is married with nine children. Currently three of her children are in school.

Ama is a petty trader who trades in tomatoes, yams, onions, beans, maize, dried fish etc. on top of table in the local market. She has been in this business for the past thirty years.

She is, however, convinced that her business can grow better with increased capital. Therefore she is requesting a loan to buy more tubers of yams, baskets of tomatoes, onions, bags of maize and beans to increased her stock and earn more income to support her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase yams, tomatoes, onions, maize and beans

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a very hard working woman who lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is 42 years old and married with 5 children.

Elizabeth sells foodstuffs at retail prices to make a living. She has been in this business for a long time. She sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed her children.

Elizabeth hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter, 29 years old, has been a green grocer for three years in Kitengela, a small town near Nairobi. He sells sukuma wiki (kale), cabbages, and tomatoes, and is requesting his first loan from Faulu for Kes. 20,000 to buy more groceries to sell.  Describing himself as innovative and hardworking, Peter's goals are to succeed in life and expand his business. He would also like to eventually expand to wholesale supply.

loans.use: To add stock

loans.name: Ozodjon

texts.en:
K. Ozodjon is a 43-year-old married man with three children. He is a hard-working man who, while continuing to work another job, started his own business as a source of additional income and savings in case of unemployment. He knew many people who purchased cattle, and this motivated him to start his own business six years ago. Over time, Ozodjon has increased his cattle sales and he is proud to say that the business has been running well. Now Ozodjon needs additional capital to expand his business. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni to purchase additional cattle to sell. More specifically, he will reinvest the loan proceeds and grow the business, as he has been doing. Ozodjon and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in helping to expand his business and helping them give their children a better quality of life.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 49 years old. She has four kids who are currently in school. She trades in maize in the local market in her community. She requests a loan to enable her to buy more maize to grow her business and scale up sales. She says her major challenge is getting herself a container shop where she can sell her stock.  She hopes to increase her savings to acquire a shop.

loans.use: To purchase maize in bulk.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther sells drinks at the market. She is 46 years old and married with two children. With her profit, she helps her family. She is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en: Iyad is a young Palestinian man living in Jerusalem, he is married with three young children.  He requested $3000 US loan from FATEN to do some maintenance for his taxi since this taxi is the only source of income for his family.  Iyad requested the loan from FATEN through its branch in Bethlehem since FATEN employees can't enter Jerusalem without permits.  Iyad appears in the picture next to his taxi.

loans.use: Maintenance for the taxi

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas N. is a 45-year-old married father of three children. He lives with his family in Mshomoroni, Mombasa. He has a yard in Mshomoroni where he sells timber and firewood. He has been in this business for 10 years and considers his business a success. Thomas was introduced to KADET by a friend and he is currently accessing his first loan. With the money, he intends to buy more timber and some rollers for machines he uses in his work.

He hopes to now open another timber yard and even expand to other areas of Mombasa. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase timber and rollers for his machine.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Sandra is 38 years old. She is a wife and mother of two children who are currently in school. She sells clothes, linen and fabrics. Sandra is constrained by funds to run the business. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up her business progress. She believes the loan will help her to purchase good quality and large quantity merchandise to upgrade her inventory. She wants to use the loan to buy different kinds of fabrics, linen and clothes in bulk. It is her greatest desire to expand her shop and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Zakaria Kingori

texts.en:
Zakaria, 25 years old and married with one son, has a shop in Kiringu Kikuyu where he sells mobile phone accessories. In the business for about two years, he earns a profit of approximately 40000 kenyan shillings a month.

Zakaria has never borrowed from any other MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. He wants to use the loan to buy more stocks of mobile phone accessories in order to meet the demand of his clients. He hopes to open another outlet in town that will be fully stocked with more than a million kenyan shillings worth of merchandise. He also wants to import accessories and become a wholesaler one day.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To add more stocks of mobile phone accessories

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a hard working man. He is married with 4 children and he is 42 years old. His wife is a petty trader. His eldest child is 16 years old. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. He sells medicines at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to own a maternity home in the future. He has been in this business for a long time. Joseph is requesting for a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Marie-Claire

texts.fr: G. Marie-Claire est née vers 1970 et est mariée à AHOUANSOU Cyprien, un revendeur. Le couple a sept enfants, dont quatre sont à leur charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Marie-Claire vit avec son mari et ses enfants depuis 13 ans à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Marie-Claire supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Marie-Claire n'a pas été à l'école. Cela fait près de 7 ans que Marie-Claire vend des bois de chauffage à Ekpè, pour subvenir à ses besoins. C'est à Pahou dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin, que Marie-Claire s'approvisionne. Marie-Claire a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. En vue de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Marie-Claire sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Marie-Claire was born in 1970 and is married to Ahouansou Cyprien, a re-seller. The couple has 7 children, 4 of whom are still in their care. All of the children attend school. For the past 13 years, Marie-Claire has lived with her husband and their children in Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. With her husband, Marie-Claire pays for the needs of her family. Marie-Claire did not attend school. For 7 years, Marie-Claire has sold firewood in Ekpè, in order to provide for her family's needs. Marie-Claire supplies herself in Pahou, in the district of Atlantique in Bénin. Marie-Claire has benefitted from one loan from ALIDé, which she fully repaid. In order to strengthen her business and satisfy more of her clientele, Marie-Claire is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood in bulk

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is married with three children. She is forty years old and a trader. She runs a mother care shop and has sold assorted child care materials like dippers, napkins, pampers, soaps, etc. for about ten years now. She does not have sufficient working capital to run her business. With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory. She would be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To purchase mother care products in bulk.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. She is married with 3 children, and she is 40 years old. She sells drinks in front of her house in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000. She will use this loan to invest in a business selling drinks which she will buy in bulk to get a better price. She hopes to expand and gives her children a better education. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 48 years old. She is a widow and has two children. All her children are still in the basic school.

Gladys trades in jewelry and has been in business for the past 8 years. Gladys buys her goods from the big shops in Accra. She hawks with her goods from house to house and also treks to nearby markets to sell.

Gladys wants to use her loan to buy jewels in bulk so she can trek to various markets and make enough income to support her kids education.

loans.use: To purchase assorted jewelry in bulk.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin is married with 3 children. She is 42 years old. She sells colorful sarongs and laces at retail and wholesale prices to her customers in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She has been in this business for a long time. The demands for her sarongs are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. Toyin is requesting for a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. Toyin says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Shokir

texts.en:
T. Shokir, a 46-year-old married father of two, breeds calves and sells dairy products to the local people and dairy factories. The difficult circumstances and hardships in his life made him recognize the value of work from a very young age. For about six years he has been purchasing young cattle in the local market, fattening and then selling them. Raising livestock is the main income source in his family. Thus Shokir wakes up early every morning to feed his calves and cows with the goal of selling them at the best price in the local market when they have grown enough. Shokir`s main goal is to provide education for his children, and with this purpose in mind, he has applied for a loan in the amount of 5000 Somoni to buy calves in order to expand his business. Let's support this hard-working man and hold our hands out to help him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase calves to expand the business.

loans.name: Lora

texts.en:
Lora is single, fair in complexion, and she is hardworking and focused. She is 30 years old and lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria.

Lora hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She believes that having an assortment of drinks, both gin and soft drinks, will increase her sales. She wants to expand her business in order to meet her needs.

Nora says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Susan Ambui

texts.en:
Ambui is married. She has been blessed with four children, who are all grown. She operates a boutique where she sells mattress covers, curtains, pillow cases, bed sheets, towels and blankets. She started this business a year ago.

Previously she was running a retail shop. Her business is located in an area with huge potential for growth. Her main customers are local residents and walk-ins.

Her major challenges are the fluctuating weather patterns. During dry season the demand is very low as the focus is on food items. She is requesting financial assistance of 20,000 KES to enable her to increase her stock of blankets and mattress covers.

loans.use: add to stock of mattress covers and blankets to sell

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en:
Fumilayo is 28 years old. She is married with three children. Her husband is a business man. Her eldest child is 8 years old and the youngest child is 4 years old.

She sells for long hours to meet the needs of her family. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan amount 100,000 NGN to buy more groceries to sell. She says thanks to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Beatrice Nyamboke

texts.en:
Beatrice is 56 years old and married with four children. She is building some rental houses to add to what she has in Mwiki center. She has been in the business for about one year and earns a profit of approximately $240 a month.

She was introduced to KADET by a friend after moving from another micro-finance agency. She wants to use this loan to finish the construction of her rental houses in order to meet her clients' demands. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To finish construction of rental houses for her rental business

loans.name: Narzullajon

texts.en:
A. Narzullajon is a hardworking and determined man. From the time he was very young, he was characterized as an excellent student. He finished his studies, but with the difficult economic situation in the country, he could not find work in any company.

Narzullajon decided to invest his small savings to start his own business selling rice at the market. Over time he expanded his business, and now it is the sole source of income for his family, including his wife and three children. Due to the high demand for his products, and because of their excellent quality, size and flavor, Narzullajon has decided to apply for a loan of 4,000 TJS to buy more goods to sell. This will allow him to earn more and to improve his living. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase rice for increasing the range of goods he sells

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is twenty seven years old and single. She is a trader, and has been selling jeans clothing, blouses and skirts, women's slippers and dressing bags for the past two years. Gloria says she has limited capital and believes the loan will help her to have the resources to purchase good quality and large quantities, which will increase sales. She wants to use the loan to purchase jeans clothes, ladies' wear and slippers to increase her inventory. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase assorted used clothes in bulk.
